column4: can someone explain what a symlink is in this advice i found?  "i created a script named it "S38umount-cifs" and placed it in /etc/init.d/ with a symlink in /etc/rc6.d/ and that works just great."
read the manpage for the 'ln' command by typing 'man ln' in a terminal
symlink is a symbolic link, that is a "file that points to another file"
ok starting to understand.  perhaps that snipped of advice i c/p'ed does not contail all the info i need.

oh wait.  the snippet was "and named it "S38umount-cifs" and placed it in /etc/init.d/ with a symlink in /etc/rc6.d/ and that works just great."  should i create a dummy file symlinked to this umount-cfs script?
from that snipped i conclude that someone wanted to umount a cifs at shutdown, so he created a script in /etc/init.d and made a link to /etc/rc6.d to make the sysvinit init system run it at shutdown
what is it you want to do, anyways?

my network processes are terminated on shutdown before shares umounted.  so yes.  i just want to be sure i am understanding which direction i am symlinking this.  so i create a script whatever.sh and put it in /etc/init.d/, then create a 2nd file in /etc/rc6.d/ and symlink to the file in init.d?  or the reverse?
the numbers of the symlinks in /etc/rc6.d determine the order in which the scripts are called
ok that's golden info.  definitely some of the context i was missing
